headline.main: Kansas City: Refining a Midwest Cuisine

docs.abstract: Dennis Ray Wheaton travel article on eating out in Kansas City discusses restaurants Lidia's Kansas City, Plaza III Steakhouse, American Restaurant, Stolen Grill and Stroud's; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: DESPITE what you may have heard, you don't have to be a barbecue fanatic to eat well in Kansas City. True, residents are justly proud of their world-class barbecue joints and steakhouses, and many a meal involves mashed potatoes, biscuits and gravy. But possibilities extend into more sophisticated realms. The already lively dining scene in this prosperous metropolis has been energized by the brand-new Lidia's, an ambitious restaurant with roots in New York and Trieste. Storefront ethnic restaurants are popping up everywhere, but what's most notable is how well the new American style of cooking stands up to more famous American restaurants on either coast. Kansas City chefs defer to no one in refining local styles while seeking out the best regional farm products as well as ingredients flown in from around the world. Even the toniest places, however, shun nouvellishly small portions for Midwestern largesse.

docs.abstract: Joanne Starkey reviews Traviata, Italian restaurant in Northport, LI; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE white house by the side of Route 25A in Northport has never looked better. Traviata, the new occupant, is spiffy on the outside and glowing within. This was formerly the site of La Capannina and, years before that, Casa Semprini, both highly regarded Italians. Traviata, like the previous restaurants here, has a formal Old World atmosphere: white tablecloths, carpeting, gilt-framed mirrors and tiny, flickering lanterns on the tables. Diaphanous, brocade-like curtains do a good job of admitting light while blocking the view of the traffic outside.

headline.main: The Cuisine Challenges the Hot Spots

docs.abstract: Joanne Starkey reviews Oakdale House restaurant in Oakdale, Long Island; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: CAN this be Oakdale? The dishes coming out of the kitchen at the Oakdale House resemble the towering creations found at trendy Manhattan restaurants and Hamptons hot spots. Paper-thin fans of fried potato slices, long, curved spears of fried plantain; skewers of fresh rosemary and clumps of frizzled sweet potato threads all point to serious efforts by the chef. The food here is especially noteworthy when compared to the fare at nearby fish houses, casual cafes and pubs. Food aside, the Oakdale House is very much like its laid-back neighbors. It has a no-reservations policy (except for parties of six or more) that results in long waits for patrons. One Saturday night, we were told the wait would be about 45 minutes. An hour and 40 minutes later we were finally shown to our table. By that time even the nothing-special rolls tasted like princely fare to our starved crew.

headline.kicker: At the Nation's Table: Los Angeles
headline.main: Chefs Make Converts To French Cuisine

docs.abstract: Club Culinaire Francais introduces diners to the many French chefs in Los Angeles through its Chef a Table program; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: A Club Culinaire Francais program to introduce diners to the many varied French chefs of Los Angeles is also proving useful to the chefs, who are introducing new dimensions of their cuisine. More than 60 diners were at Pascal's last week for the second ''Chefs a Table'' of the year. The program, now in its third year, lets diners regularly sit, eat and chat with the chefs. One highlight is a French picnic in rustic Topanga Canyon.

headline.main: Cuisine Raises Debate on Cruelty and Culture

docs.abstract: Merchants at about a dozen Chinese stores around San Francisco and their tradition of stocking and selling freshly killed animals have run headlong into animal-rights movement; animal-rights advocates say animals are being overcrowded, underfed and then inhumanely killed at Chinese markets in Chinatown and other parts of city; thousands who live and shop in largest Chinese cultural enclave on West Coast argue that meat is fresher and healthier when animals is killed immediately before consumption; issue is pending before Animal Control and Welfare Commission; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: There is a loud whapping in the background as May Chang explains the marketing philosophy of her bustling food store in Chinatown, whapping that mixes with a clamor of orders in Cantonese and an occasional series of thumps. The whapping is the sound of meat cleavers coming down on the heads of live turtles and frogs. The thumps are live fish striking the butcher block before scaling. The orders are for more.

headline.main: Flavorful Indian Cuisine in White Plains

docs.lead_paragraph: STILL delightful after 22 years, the Bengal Tiger continues to grow and satisfy the county's taste for the seductive flavors of Indian cuisine, and the food here has never been better. Not content to rest on his restaurant's past success, Simpson Kalathara introduces new items with welcome regularity, and right now his comprehensive menu lists dishes representing almost every corner of India from the Himalayas to Cape Comorin. Breads are serious here. New and usually offered only toward weekends are masala dosas; share one as an appetizer. These bronzed, foot-long cylinders of smooth paper-thin rice pancakes come filled with a delectable mixture of potato, peas, onion and mild spices. Chef's special nan stuffed with minced chicken and nuts and puffy onion kulcha with onions and seasonings made fine openers as well. But plain, fluffy nan remained our choice for the best bread with which to sop up the lovely entree sauces.

headline.main: Chinese Cuisine As Smogasbord For the Intellect

docs.lead_paragraph: There were burning questions about peanut oil. Should you really be using it? (yes) and how much? (enough). There was a long debate on just how hot is hot when it comes to heating a wok. (Until it steams, it was revealed, although most cookbooks won't say so, because editors fear liability suits that could result from a kitchen that burns to the ground.)

headline.main: Searching the Soul Of French Cuisine

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST summer, I returned to my native France with a single-minded journalistic mission. There has been much discussion recently suggesting that French cuisine is in the doldrums, bereft of new ideas. On this nostalgic journey I set out to determine: where is French cuisine today? And, equally important, where is it heading? After three months, 10,000 miles and 60 restaurants, the answers were palpable, though not simple. In short, French cooking, from Nice to Normandy, is going through another of its periodic revolutions, only this time it is more subtle. And it is a somewhat contradictory movement, with leading chefs taking one step forward and one step backward at the same time. I'll try to explain. First, a little background.
